docs.lead_paragraph: The debate over whether the government should offer a public insurance plan is all about competition. How competitive is the private insurance market right now? It depends on where you live. As a general rule, the larger, more densely populated states have the most choice -- and even the biggest insurer controls only a minority share of the market. According to statistics from the American Medical Association, the leading insurance provider in California covers 24 percent of the population, while in New York the figure is 26 percent and in Florida, 30 percent.
docs.abstract: Debate over whether government should offer public health insurance plan has focused on competition; some members of Senate Finance Committee, which is taking lead on health care legislation, come from states where insurance market is highly concentrated; single insurer controls 70 percent or more of market in nine states and at least half of market in 17 other states; map (M)
docs.snippet: The debate over whether the government should offer a public insurance plan is all about competition. How competitive is the private insurance market right now? It depends on where you live.      As a general rule, the larger, more densely populated...

docs.abstract: As the public health care option gets hammered by a campaign of disinformation, the co-op model deserves a fair hearing.
docs.snippet: As the public health care option gets hammered by a campaign of disinformation, the co-op model deserves a fair hearing.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama, who for two days has not weighed in on the vocal frustration among liberal Democrats over whether a public insurance plan will ultimately be part of his health care agenda, has decided to step into the fray on Thursday in an online meeting.

headline.main: Obama to Hold Online Meeting on Health Care

docs.abstract: President Obama, who for two days has not weighed in on the vocal frustration among liberal Democrats over his health care agenda, will step into the fray on Thursday.
docs.snippet: President Obama, who for two days has not weighed in on the vocal frustration among liberal Democrats over his health care agenda, will step into the fray on Thursday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa and a member of the Senate Finance Committee, shares his concerns about health care reform with CNBC's Jane Wells.

headline.sub: A Member of the "Gang of Six" Shares His Concerns

docs.snippet: Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa and a member of the Senate Finance Committee, shares his concerns about health care reform with CNBC's Jane Wells.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, called President Obama and Speaker Nancy Pelosi "intellectually dishonest" on Tuesday, saying that Democrats were using the flap over end-of-life consultations to divert attention away from health care legislation currently being considered in the House.

headline.main: Grassley Calls Obama and Pelosi 'Intellectually Dishonest'

docs.abstract: Sen. Charles E. Grassley says he will not support legislation that requires making judgments on whether "to value life at the end of life any more than at age 30 or 20."
docs.snippet: Sen. Charles E. Grassley says he will not support legislation that requires making judgments on whether "to value life at the end of life any more than at age 30 or 20."

docs.lead_paragraph: When politicians talk about prevention and health care, they are prone to sweeping statements about how preventive services not only keep people healthy but also save money. Just last Sunday, President Obama wrote in The Times:
docs.abstract: Preventive health care doesn't always save money. Often, it raises costs.
docs.snippet: Preventive health care doesn't always save money. Often, it raises costs.

docs.lead_paragraph: The health care debate is introducing the public to odd new terminologies, the "hanging chads" of this political season.
docs.abstract: Tell us what you need to know.
docs.snippet: Tell us what you need to know.

docs.lead_paragraph: Don't look now, but "co-op" may have become one of the most important words in the debate over health care reform.
docs.abstract: Health cooperatives are emerging as an alternative to a public insurance option in the debate over health care reform. And some Democrats are not happy about it.
docs.snippet: Health cooperatives are emerging as an alternative to a public insurance option in the debate over health care reform. And some Democrats are not happy about it.

docs.lead_paragraph: Updated, 2 p.m. | Saying it spends nearly as much on health insurance for its workers as it does on coffee, Starbucks recently announced that it would increase the amount that eligible employees need to contribute to keep their health care coverage.

headline.main: Starbucks Workers Protest Rise in Health Premiums

docs.abstract: A group of Starbucks employees gathered on Monday evening to protest increases to the amount they would have to pay for health insurance.
docs.snippet: A group of Starbucks employees gathered on Monday evening to protest increases to the amount they would have to pay for health insurance.

docs.lead_paragraph: BB&T, the southeast regional bank that agreed Friday to buy assets from Colonial Bank, said it was making an offering of $750 million of its common stock.
docs.abstract: BB&T, the southeast regional bank that agreed Friday to buy assets of lender Colonial Bank, said it is making an offering of $750 million of its common stock.
docs.snippet: BB&T, the southeast regional bank that agreed Friday to buy assets of lender Colonial Bank, said it is making an offering of $750 million of its common stock.
